title: اختبار مطور SharePoint C# المتقدم
description: A 150-question comprehensive exam for C# SharePoint developers, covering SSOM, CSOM, SPFx, REST APIs, Architecture, Security, and Modern Development.

questions.text: What is the top-level container in an on-premises SharePoint farm that is associated with one or more IIS websites?
questions.explanation: A Web Application is the top-level logical unit, created in Central Administration, which maps to an IIS website and is associated with content databases and authentication providers.

questions.text: What is a SharePoint Feature?
answers: A package of SharePoint elements (like lists, content types, or web parts) that can be activated or deactivated at a specific scope.
A premium license required for advanced capabilities.
A specific type of SharePoint site template.
questions.correctAnswer: A package of SharePoint elements (like lists, content types, or web parts) that can be activated or deactivated at a specific scope.
questions.explanation: Features are the fundamental unit of deployment in classic SharePoint, allowing for modular activation of functionality at the Farm, WebApplication, Site (Collection), or Web (Site) scope.

questions.text: A 'Content Type' is a reusable collection of settings for a specific category of content. What does it primarily define?
answers: A set of Site Columns (metadata) and an optional document template.
The visual design and branding of a page.
The type of database used to store the content.
questions.correctAnswer: A set of Site Columns (metadata) and an optional document template.
questions.explanation: Content Types allow you to define a schema (via Site Columns) and a template (e.g., a .dotx for a 'Contract' content type) that can be reused across multiple lists and libraries.

questions.text: What is the logical hierarchy of core SharePoint containers?
answers: Web Application -> Site -> Site Collection -> List
Farm -> Web Application -> Site Collection -> Site (Web)
Site Collection -> Farm -> Web Application -> Site
questions.correctAnswer: Farm -> Web Application -> Site Collection -> Site (Web)
questions.explanation: The Farm is the entire server installation. It contains Web Applications, which in turn contain one or more Site Collections (SPSite). Each Site Collection has a top-level Site (SPWeb) and can have many subsites (SPWebs).

questions.text: A 'Site Column' is a reusable column definition that can be used in multiple lists within a site collection.
questions.explanation: Defining a column as a 'Site Column' at the root site (SPWeb) of a site collection (SPSite) allows it to be added to any list or content type within that collection, ensuring consistency.

questions.text: In SharePoint Online, what is the primary replacement for classic 'Subsites'?
answers: Hub Sites and associated Site Collections
There is no replacement; subsites are still the recommended practice.
questions.correctAnswer: Hub Sites and associated Site Collections
questions.explanation: The modern SharePoint architecture favors a 'flat' structure of separate Site Collections, which are then associated using a Hub Site for shared navigation and search.

questions.text: Which SharePoint service application is responsible for indexing content and serving query results?
questions.explanation: The Search Service Application is the powerful engine responsible for crawling content sources, creating an index, and providing a query API for end-users and custom applications.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the 'Managed Metadata' service?
answers: To manage user permissions and groups.
To provide a central 'Term Store' for creating and managing a formal taxonomy (keywords, hierarchies) for tagging content.
To connect to external databases like SQL Server.
To manage the deployment of C# code.
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a central 'Term Store' for creating and managing a formal taxonomy (keywords, hierarchies) for tagging content.
questions.explanation: The Term Store allows organizations to define a consistent, hierarchical set of terms (a taxonomy) that can be used in 'Managed Metadata' columns across the farm.

questions.text: SharePoint 'Lists' and 'Document Libraries' are both stored in SQL Server tables.
questions.explanation: All content in SharePoint (list items, documents, pages) is stored within a 'Content Database' in SQL Server. SharePoint's object model abstracts this database complexity away from the developer.

questions.text: A ___ is a special type of document library used to store and display web pages.
questions.explanation: In classic publishing sites, the 'Pages Library' (or 'Site Pages' in modern sites) stores the .aspx files that are rendered as pages in the browser.

questions.text: Business Connectivity Services (BCS) are used to...
answers: Connect SharePoint to external data sources (like SQL, web services) and display that data in 'External Lists'.
Provide a secure connection for mobile devices.
questions.correctAnswer: Connect SharePoint to external data sources (like SQL, web services) and display that data in 'External Lists'.
questions.explanation: BCS (formerly BDC) allows SharePoint to surface data from external systems as if it were a native SharePoint list, including create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a 'Team Site' and a 'Communication Site' in modern SharePoint Online?
answers: Team Sites are for collaboration (many-to-many), while Communication Sites are for broadcasting (few-to-many).
Team Sites cannot have document libraries, while Communication Sites can.
Team Sites are only for on-premises, while Communication Sites are only for Online.
There is no functional difference, only a visual one.
questions.correctAnswer: Team Sites are for collaboration (many-to-many), while Communication Sites are for broadcasting (few-to-many).
questions.explanation: Team Sites are connected to a Microsoft 365 Group and are designed for a team to work together. Communication Sites are for sharing news and information to a broad audience.

questions.text: In the Server-Side Object Model (SSOM), which C# class represents a Site Collection?
questions.explanation: `SPSite` is the class used to instantiate an object representing a single site collection, typically with `new SPSite(url)`.

questions.text: In SSOM, which C# class represents a single Site (which could be a top-level site or a subsite)?
questions.explanation: `SPWeb` represents a single site. You typically get it from an `SPSite` object using `site.OpenWeb()` or `site.RootWeb`.

questions.text: What is the primary best practice for C# memory management when using `SPSite` and `SPWeb` objects in SSOM?
answers: Store them in static variables for reuse.
Always dispose of them using a `using` block or by calling `.Dispose()` in a `finally` block.
Let the .NET Garbage Collector handle them automatically.
questions.correctAnswer: Always dispose of them using a `using` block or by calling `.Dispose()` in a `finally` block.
questions.explanation: `SPSite` and `SPWeb` objects hold unmanaged resources (like database connections). Failing to dispose of them will cause severe memory leaks on the server. The `using` pattern is the standard.

questions.text: You can use the Server-Side Object Model (SSOM) to query a SharePoint Online tenant.
questions.explanation: SSOM code *must* run on the SharePoint server itself (in the farm). It cannot be used to remotely query SharePoint Online; you must use CSOM or the REST API for that.

questions.text: In SSOM, what is the purpose of `SPSecurity.RunWithElevatedPrivileges(delegate { ... })`?
answers: To run code as the current user but with a new `SPSite` object.
To run a block of C# code under the identity of the Application Pool account (typically the Farm Admin).
To temporarily disable security trimming in search results.
To run C# code on the client's browser.
questions.correctAnswer: To run a block of C# code under the identity of the Application Pool account (typically the Farm Admin).
questions.explanation: This is used to bypass the current user's permissions for a specific, trusted operation, but it is a security risk if used improperly. Note that `SPSite` and `SPWeb` objects must be re-instantiated *inside* the delegate.

questions.text: Where must the C# assembly (DLL) for a full-trust SSOM solution (e.g., a classic web part or event receiver) be deployed?
answers: In the Global Assembly Cache (GAC) on each SharePoint server in the farm.
questions.correctAnswer: In the Global Assembly Cache (GAC) on each SharePoint server in the farm.
questions.explanation: To run with full trust and be accessible by the SharePoint application, the strongly-named assembly must be deployed to the GAC on all Web Front-End (WFE) and Application servers.

questions.text: In SSOM, what is the purpose of an `SPQuery` object?
answers: To execute a SQL query against the content database.
To define a query (using CAML) to retrieve items from an `SPList` using the `list.GetItems(query)` method.
To query the User Profile Service.
To search the entire farm for content.
questions.correctAnswer: To define a query (using CAML) to retrieve items from an `SPList` using the `list.GetItems(query)` method.
questions.explanation: `SPQuery` is the primary object for building and executing CAML queries against a specific SharePoint list or library.

questions.text: The `SPContext.Current` object is available in all C# SSOM applications, including console applications.
questions.explanation: `SPContext.Current` is only available within an active HTTP request (e.g., in a web part, application page, or event receiver). In a console app or timer job, it is `null`, and you must instantiate `SPSite` manually.

questions.text: Which SSOM class would you use to add or delete a list from a site?
questions.explanation: You access the collection of lists via the `web.Lists` property (which is an `SPListCollection`) and then call its `Add` or `Delete` methods.

questions.text: What is an 'Event Receiver' in SSOM?
answers: A JavaScript function that runs on the client.
A piece of C# code that runs on the server in response to a SharePoint event (e.g., 'ItemAdding' or 'ItemAdded').
A dashboard for viewing server event logs.
questions.correctAnswer: A piece of C# code that runs on the server in response to a SharePoint event (e.g., 'ItemAdding' or 'ItemAdded').
questions.explanation: Event Receivers are the classic way to enforce business logic or trigger actions, running either synchronously (before the action) or asynchronously (after the action).

questions.text: LINQ to SharePoint can be used with the Server-Side Object Model (SSOM).
questions.explanation: SSOM supports LINQ to SharePoint, which allows C# developers to write LINQ queries (e.g., `from item in list.Items where ...`) that are internally converted to CAML queries.

questions.text: To create a new list item in SSOM, you call `list.Items.Add()`, set the field values, and then call `___`.
questions.explanation: After adding a new `SPListItem` and setting its properties, you must call the `item.Update()` method to commit the changes to the content database.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between `site.OpenWeb()` and `site.AllWebs[indexOrName]`?
answers: `OpenWeb` returns a new `SPWeb` object that must be disposed, while `AllWebs` returns a cached object that should not be disposed.
`OpenWeb` is for subsites only, while `AllWebs` includes the root web.
questions.correctAnswer: `OpenWeb` returns a new `SPWeb` object that must be disposed, while `AllWebs` returns a cached object that should not be disposed.
questions.explanation: This is a critical memory management concept. `site.OpenWeb()` creates a new object; `site.AllWebs` (or `site.RootWeb`) returns a reference from the context's cache.

questions.text: A ___ is a type of SSOM solution that runs in a separate, low-trust worker process and has a very limited API.
questions.explanation: Sandboxed Solutions were a precursor to the Add-in model, designed for multi-tenant environments (like SPO) where farm-level code was not allowed. They are now deprecated.

questions.text: SSOM code is typically debugged by attaching the Visual Studio debugger to the `___` process on the SharePoint server.
questions.explanation: `w3wp.exe` is the IIS worker process that hosts the SharePoint Web Application. Attaching to it allows for server-side debugging of web parts, event receivers, etc.

questions.text: To retrieve a single `SPListItem` by its ID in SSOM, you should use:
answers: It's not possible to get a single item.
questions.explanation: `list.GetItemById(id)` is the most direct and performant way. Using the indexer `list.Items[id]` is incorrect as `list.Items` is not indexed by item ID.

questions.text: SSOM timer jobs (classes inheriting from `SPJobDefinition`) are C# classes scheduled to run on a recurring basis.
questions.explanation: Timer jobs are the classic on-premises way to create background tasks (like nightly cleanups) that run on a schedule defined in Central Administration.

questions.text: The `SPContext.Current.Web` object should be disposed after use.
questions.explanation: Objects obtained directly from `SPContext` are managed by the context itself and *should not* be disposed. Disposing them can break other components on the page.

questions.text: What is the primary C# class used as the entry point for all .NET Client-Side Object Model (CSOM) operations?
questions.explanation: The `ClientContext` (from the `Microsoft.SharePoint.Client` namespace) is the main object that manages the connection to the SharePoint site and batches operations.

questions.text: In CSOM, which method is used to *stage* an object or property for retrieval from the server?
questions.explanation: `Load()` tells the context that you *want* to retrieve data about this object (e.g., `context.Load(web, w => w.Title)`). The data is not fetched until `ExecuteQuery()` is called.

questions.text: In CSOM, which method actually sends the batched request to the SharePoint server and retrieves the results?
questions.explanation: All operations (Loads, updates, creations) are batched locally. `ExecuteQuery()` sends this batch to the server as a single XML request and populates the client objects with the return values.

questions.text: .NET CSOM (C#) can be used to develop console applications, web APIs, and desktop apps that interact with SharePoint.
questions.explanation: Because CSOM is a client library, it can be used from *any* .NET application (console, WPF, ASP.NET) that can reference the DLLs and connect to the SharePoint server's `_vti_bin/client.svc` endpoint.

questions.text: What is the JavaScript equivalent of the .NET `ClientContext`?
questions.explanation: The JavaScript Object Model (JSOM) mirrors the .NET CSOM. You create a new `SP.ClientContext(siteUrl)` to begin operations.

questions.text: In C# CSOM, how do you specify which properties of an object you want to retrieve to optimize a query?
answers: It's not possible; all properties are always loaded.
Using a `select` statement in a CAML query.
Using a Lambda expression in the `Load()` method (e.g., `Load(web, w => w.Title, w => w.Lists)`).
questions.correctAnswer: Using a Lambda expression in the `Load()` method (e.g., `Load(web, w => w.Title, w => w.Lists)`).
questions.explanation: This is a key performance optimization. By specifying only the properties you need (e.g., `w => w.Title`), you significantly reduce the amount of data sent over the network.

questions.text: The C# CSOM libraries (`Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.dll` and `Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.Runtime.dll`) must be installed in the GAC on the SharePoint server.
questions.explanation: These are *client* libraries. They are included with your client application (e.g., in the `bin` folder of your console app) and run on the client machine, *not* the server.

questions.text: To query a list using CAML in C# CSOM, you create a `___` object.
questions.explanation: Similar to `SPQuery` in SSOM, you use the `CamlQuery` class, set its `ViewXml` property, and pass it to the `list.GetItems(query)` method.

questions.text: In JSOM, `executeQueryAsync` requires two callback functions. What are they for?
questions.explanation: Because JavaScript is asynchronous, you must provide a success callback function to run when the data is returned, and a failure callback to handle any errors.

questions.text: What type of authentication is typically used when connecting to SharePoint Online with C# CSOM?
answers: Modern Authentication (OAuth) via an App Registration, or using `SharePointOnlineCredentials` (legacy).
questions.correctAnswer: Modern Authentication (OAuth) via an App Registration, or using `SharePointOnlineCredentials` (legacy).
questions.explanation: SharePoint Online uses cloud-based identity. Modern apps use OAuth 2.0 (e.g., MSAL), while older console apps used the `SharePointOnlineCredentials` class with a username and password (which is now discouraged).

questions.text: To create a new list item using C# CSOM, you use the `ListItemCreationInformation` class.
questions.explanation: You create a `ListItemCreationInformation` object, pass it to `list.AddItem()`, set the new item's properties, call `item.Update()`, and then `context.ExecuteQuery()`.

questions.text: The primary C# namespace for CSOM is `___`.
questions.explanation: The core libraries are `Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.dll` and `Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.Runtime.dll`, found in the corresponding NuGet package.

questions.text: You can use C# CSOM to interact with both Lists/Libraries and the User Profile Service.
questions.explanation: CSOM has been extended to cover many areas, including User Profiles (using `Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.UserProfiles.dll`), Search, and Taxonomy.

questions.text: What is the CSOM `LoadQuery` method used for?
answers: To load a CAML query from an XML file.
To execute a LINQ query and return the results as a new collection, rather than populating an existing object.
To load the search query service.
questions.correctAnswer: To execute a LINQ query and return the results as a new collection, rather than populating an existing object.
questions.explanation: `LoadQuery` is used with LINQ-style queries (e.g., `context.LoadQuery(web.Lists.Where(l => ...))`) and is executed by `ExecuteQuery()`. The result is a new `IEnumerable<T>`.

questions.text: When updating a list item with CSOM, you must call `item.Update()` *before* calling `context.ExecuteQuery()`.
questions.explanation: `item.Update()` stages the 'update' operation in the local batch. `context.ExecuteQuery()` is what sends that batched operation to the server.

questions.text: The JavaScript file `sp.js` is required to use the JavaScript Object Model (JSOM).
questions.explanation: To use JSOM, you must ensure `sp.js` (and its dependencies like `sp.runtime.js`) are loaded on the page, often using `SP.SOD.executeFunc('sp.js', 'SP.ClientContext', ...)`.

questions.text: Exception handling for C# CSOM should be done using a standard `try...catch` block around the `___` call.
questions.explanation: Since all batched operations are sent to the server on `ExecuteQuery()`, this is the line of code that will throw an exception (like `ServerException`) if anything fails on the server.

questions.text: What is the `_spPageContextInfo` object in JSOM?
answers: A JavaScript object available on classic SharePoint pages that contains current context information (like `webAbsoluteUrl`).
The main JSOM client context object.
A C# class for managing page context.
A JSON file containing page metadata.
questions.correctAnswer: A JavaScript object available on classic SharePoint pages that contains current context information (like `webAbsoluteUrl`).
questions.explanation: This object is automatically added to the page by SharePoint and is very useful for getting the current site URL, user ID, etc., to initialize a JSOM `SP.ClientContext`.

questions.text: In C# CSOM, `ClientContext.Credentials` is used to provide authentication details.
questions.explanation: You would set this property, for example: `context.Credentials = new SharePointOnlineCredentials(username, securePassword)` for legacy SPO auth or use an OAuth token.

questions.text: The CSOM `ListItemCollection` object loads all items in the list by default when you call `context.Load(list.Items)`.
questions.explanation: This is a common pitfall. By default, `list.Items` does *not* include the item data. You must use a `CamlQuery` (even an empty one) with `list.GetItems(query)` to retrieve the actual items.

questions.text: What is the standard base URL prefix for all SharePoint REST API calls?
questions.explanation: All REST API endpoints are relative to the site and begin with `_api/`, for example: `https://[sitecollection]/_api/web/lists`.

questions.text: Which HTTP verb is used with the REST API to retrieve information (e.g., get all lists)?
questions.explanation: A standard `GET` request is used for all read operations, e.g., `GET _api/web/lists`.

questions.text: Which HTTP verb is used with the REST API to create a new SharePoint list item?
questions.explanation: You `POST` the new item's data (as JSON) to the list's item collection endpoint (e.g., `_api/web/lists/getbytitle('MyList')/items`).

questions.text: To update an existing list item using the REST API, you must send a `POST` request with which HTTP header?
questions.explanation: You `POST` to the item's specific URL (e.g., `.../items(1)`). Because HTML forms only supported GET/POST, the `X-HTTP-Method` header is used to 'tunnel' the `MERGE` or `PATCH` verb.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the 'Form Digest' value (X-RequestDigest header) in REST API calls?
answers: To encrypt the data being sent.
To prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks on write operations (POST, PUT, DELETE).
To specify the OData version being used.
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks on write operations (POST, PUT, DELETE).
questions.explanation: This value is a security token that must be fetched (from `_api/contextinfo`) and included in the headers of all state-changing requests to prove the request originated from the SharePoint site.

questions.text: You can use the SharePoint REST API from any C# application (like a Web API or console app) using `HttpClient`.
questions.explanation: The REST API is platform-agnostic. Any C# application that can construct HTTP requests (using `HttpClient`) and handle JSON responses can use it.

questions.text: What does the OData (Open Data Protocol) query operator `$select` do in a REST query?
answers: Selects items based on a *condition* (e.g., `$select=Status eq 'Complete'`).
Selects the correct web to query.
questions.explanation: This is a key performance optimization, equivalent to the lambda expression in CSOM's `Load()` method. It reduces the payload size.

questions.text: What does the OData operator `$expand` do in a REST query?
answers: Increases the number of items returned.
Retrieves data from related lookups or user fields in the same call (e.g., `$expand=Author`).
questions.correctAnswer: Retrieves data from related lookups or user fields in the same call (e.g., `$expand=Author`).
questions.explanation: By default, lookup/user fields only return an ID. Using `$expand=Author` and `$select=Author/Title` will retrieve the Author's name in a single request.

questions.text: To filter results in a REST API call, you use the `___` OData operator.
questions.explanation: The `$filter` operator is used to specify conditions, e.g., `_api/web/lists/getbytitle('Tasks')/items?$filter=Status eq 'In Progress'`.

questions.text: The SharePoint REST API cannot be used to execute CAML queries.
questions.explanation: You can execute a CAML query by `POST`ing it to the `_api/web/lists/getbytitle('MyList')/getitems` endpoint.

questions.text: Which HTTP header is required to specify you are sending JSON data in a `POST` request?
questions.explanation: You must set the `Content-Type` and `Accept` headers to `application/json;odata=verbose` (or `odata=nometadata` in modern) to tell the server how to interpret your request body and format its response.

questions.text: The REST API endpoint `_api/web/lists/getbytitle('Tasks')/items(1)` is used to:
answers: Get the first item in the list.
Get the list item with ID = 1.
Get the list item in the first view.
questions.correctAnswer: Get the list item with ID = 1.
questions.explanation: The `items(ID)` syntax is the standard OData way to retrieve a single item from a collection by its unique identifier.

questions.text: Which OData operator is used for sorting in a REST query (e.g., by Title ascending)?
questions.explanation: The correct OData syntax for sorting is `$orderby=FieldName asc` (ascending) or `$orderby=FieldName desc` (descending).

questions.text: To delete a list item via the REST API, you send a `DELETE` request, which must be tunneled using `POST` and the `___` header.
questions.explanation: Similar to updates, you `POST` to the item's URL (e.g., `.../items(1)`) with the `X-HTTP-Method: DELETE` and `X-RequestDigest` headers.

questions.text: The REST API is generally considered more difficult to use from C# than the .NET CSOM.
questions.explanation: While REST is more flexible, CSOM is often easier for C# developers as it provides strongly-typed objects and handles batching/authentication (via `ClientContext`) more abstractly than raw `HttpClient` requests.

questions.text: What is the SharePoint Framework (SPFx)?
answers: A new C# framework for building SSOM solutions.
A server-side framework for building Provider-Hosted Add-ins.
A client-side framework (using TypeScript/JavaScript) for building modern web parts and extensions that run in the browser.
A .NET Core framework for querying the Microsoft Graph.
questions.correctAnswer: A client-side framework (using TypeScript/JavaScript) for building modern web parts and extensions that run in the browser.
questions.explanation: SPFx is the standard for modern SharePoint development. The code runs entirely in the user's browser, providing a fast, responsive experience, and it can query SharePoint or other APIs.

questions.text: What is the primary programming language used for SPFx development?
questions.explanation: SPFx solutions are built using TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript that adds static typing, which is then transpiled into JavaScript that runs in the browser.

questions.text: What tool is used to scaffold (create the initial files for) a new SPFx solution?
questions.explanation: You use the command-line tool Yeoman (by running `yo @microsoft/sharepoint`) to create the folder structure and initial files for a new SPFx web part or extension.

questions.text: An SPFx solution can contain C# code that runs on the server.
questions.explanation: SPFx solutions are purely client-side. If server-side C# code is needed, the SPFx web part must call a separate, independently hosted API (e.g., an Azure Function or .NET Web API).

questions.text: What are the three types of SPFx Extensions?
answers: Web Part, App Page, and Site Script
Application Customizer, Field Customizer, and Command Set
Timer Job, Event Receiver, and Feature
questions.correctAnswer: Application Customizer, Field Customizer, and Command Set
questions.explanation: Application Customizers add scripts or placeholders (e.g., headers/footers). Field Customizers customize the rendering of a field in a list. Command Sets add new buttons to list toolbars.

questions.text: What is the name of the local development server used to test SPFx web parts?
questions.explanation: When you run `gulp serve`, it opens the SharePoint Workbench, a local (or hosted) page that can load and display your developing web part for testing.

questions.text: In an SPFx web part, what object is used to make HTTP requests to the SharePoint REST API?
questions.explanation: `spHttpClient` is the recommended object as it automatically handles authentication (auth cookies) and the Form Digest value for requests to the native SharePoint API.

questions.text: To call the Microsoft Graph API from an SPFx solution, you should use the `___`.
questions.explanation: The `GraphHttpClient` (or more modern `AadHttpClientFactory`) is used to make calls to the Graph API, as it handles the OAuth bearer token retrieval automatically, based on permissions granted in the App Catalog.

questions.text: Which `gulp` task is used to bundle and package an SPFx solution into a `.sppkg` file for deployment?
questions.explanation: First you run `gulp bundle --ship` to create the production JavaScript bundles, then `gulp package-solution --ship` to create the `.sppkg` file that gets uploaded to the App Catalog.

questions.text: A C# developer cannot use their C# skills in modern SPFx development.
questions.explanation: While the front-end is TypeScript, a C# developer is crucial for building the backend APIs (e.g., Azure Functions, .NET Web APIs) that the SPFx solution calls for complex business logic or to access external systems.

questions.text: What file in an SPFx solution is used to request API permissions (e.g., for Microsoft Graph)?
questions.explanation: You add a `webApiPermissionRequests` section to the `package-solution.json` file. When the solution is deployed, an admin must approve these requests in the Admin Center.

questions.text: What is the 'property pane' in an SPFx web part?
answers: The C# class file for the web part.
The configuration panel (sidebar) that opens when a user edits the web part's properties.
The main `render()` method of the web part.
questions.correctAnswer: The configuration panel (sidebar) that opens when a user edits the web part's properties.
questions.explanation: The property pane is defined in the `getPropertyPaneConfiguration` method and allows users to configure the web part (e.g., enter text, select a list).

questions.text: SPFx web parts are *not* backward compatible with classic SharePoint pages.
questions.explanation: SPFx web parts *are* backward compatible. You can add an SPFx web part to a classic wiki or web part page, providing a good migration path.

questions.text: The SPFx `___` method is the main entry point that renders the web part's HTML.
questions.explanation: The `public render(): void { ... }` method is called by the framework to draw the web part's UI, typically by setting `this.domElement.innerHTML` or using a framework like React.

questions.text: SPFx web parts run in the security context of the currently logged-in user.
questions.explanation: SPFx is client-side code, so all API calls (like `spHttpClient`) are made using the current user's identity and permissions. There is no `RunWithElevatedPrivileges` equivalent.

questions.text: What are the two main types of SharePoint Add-ins (formerly 'Apps')?
questions.explanation: These were the two models. SharePoint-Hosted Add-ins run in the browser, while Provider-Hosted Add-ins run on a separate, external server.

questions.text: A SharePoint-Hosted Add-in can contain server-side C# code.
questions.explanation: A SharePoint-Hosted Add-in can only contain client-side assets (HTML, CSS, JavaScript/JSOM). All code runs in the browser within a special 'app web'.

questions.text: Which type of Add-in is required to run C# code (e.g., an ASP.NET Web API) on a separate server, like Azure?
questions.explanation: The 'Provider-Hosted' model means the developer provides the hosting (e.g., an Azure Web App) for their C# backend code, which then uses CSOM or REST to communicate back to SharePoint.

questions.text: What is the manifest file that defines a SharePoint Add-in and its permissions?
questions.explanation: The `AppManifest.xml` file is the core of the Add-in, defining its name, start page, and the permission scopes it requires (e.g., 'Read' on Lists).

questions.text: How does a Provider-Hosted Add-in (using C#) authenticate to SharePoint Online?
answers: By passing the user's username and password.
Using an OAuth access token, typically acquired using a client ID and secret (S2S) or certificate.
It cannot authenticate; it only allows anonymous access.
questions.correctAnswer: Using an OAuth access token, typically acquired using a client ID and secret (S2S) or certificate.
questions.explanation: The Add-in is registered in Azure AD (or AppRegNew.aspx) and uses OAuth 2.0 to get an access token, which it passes as a Bearer token in requests to SharePoint.

questions.text: A Provider-Hosted Add-in runs C# code in the `w3wp.exe` process on the SharePoint server.
questions.explanation: This is the key difference from a Farm Solution. Provider-Hosted code runs *externally* (e.g., in an Azure Web App's process), making it safe for SharePoint Online.

questions.text: What is the 'App Web' in the context of Add-ins?
answers: A special, isolated subsite created for an Add-in to store its own lists and pages.
The external ASP.NET website for a Provider-Hosted Add-in.
The App Catalog where Add-ins are stored.
A mobile-friendly version of the Add-in.
questions.correctAnswer: A special, isolated subsite created for an Add-in to store its own lists and pages.
questions.explanation: When an Add-in is installed, SharePoint can create a special, isolated 'App Web' (a subsite) where the Add-in has full control to deploy its own assets without affecting the host site.

questions.text: What is the 'Host Web' in the context of Add-ins?
answers: The external server hosting the provider code.
The main SharePoint site (Site Collection or Subsite) where the user installed and launched the Add-in.
The top-level site in the Web Application.
questions.correctAnswer: The main SharePoint site (Site Collection or Subsite) where the user installed and launched the Add-in.
questions.explanation: An Add-in often needs to read/write data to the 'Host Web' (the site it was installed on), which requires requesting permissions (e.g., 'Write' on Lists) in the `AppManifest.xml`.

questions.text: The Add-in Model is now considered the most modern and recommended way to build new customizations for SharePoint Online.
questions.explanation: The Add-in Model is largely superseded by the SharePoint Framework (SPFx) for front-end development and Azure-hosted APIs (like Azure Functions) for the backend.

questions.text: In a C# Provider-Hosted Add-in, the `___` class (from `TokenHelper.cs`) is often used to get a `ClientContext` for the Host Web.
questions.explanation: Visual Studio projects for Add-ins included a `TokenHelper.cs` utility class with methods like `GetClientContextWithContextToken` to simplify the complex OAuth authentication flow.

questions.text: What is a `.wsp` file in classic SharePoint development?
answers: A 'Web Solution Package', a cabinet file (.cab) containing all the assets (DLLs, Features, XML) for a classic solution.
questions.correctAnswer: A 'Web Solution Package', a cabinet file (.cab) containing all the assets (DLLs, Features, XML) for a classic solution.
questions.explanation: The `.wsp` file is the deployable unit for on-premises Farm Solutions or Sandboxed Solutions, typically built by Visual Studio.

questions.text: What is a 'Farm Solution'?
answers: A solution that can only be deployed to SharePoint Online.
A classic `.wsp` solution that runs with full trust, is deployed to the GAC, and has access to the full Server-Side Object Model (SSOM).
A solution that is deployed to every farm in the world.
questions.correctAnswer: A classic `.wsp` solution that runs with full trust, is deployed to the GAC, and has access to the full Server-Side Object Model (SSOM).
questions.explanation: Farm Solutions are the most powerful (and most dangerous) type of customization, as they run as part of the main SharePoint process. They are for on-premises only.

questions.text: What is a 'Sandboxed Solution'?
answers: A solution that runs with full farm administrator privileges.
A `.wsp` solution that runs in a restricted, isolated process with a limited subset of the SSOM API.
A solution that can only be deployed by a sandbox admin.
questions.correctAnswer: A `.wsp` solution that runs in a restricted, isolated process with a limited subset of the SSOM API.
questions.explanation: Sandboxed Solutions were designed for multi-tenancy (like SPO) to prevent custom code from crashing the whole farm. They are now fully deprecated in SPO and discouraged on-prem.

questions.text: A 'Feature' is defined in an XML file (Feature.xml) and can be 'scoped' to different levels. What are the four scopes?
answers: List, Library, Page, and Web Part
questions.explanation: The scope of a Feature determines where it can be activated and what elements it can contain. For example, a Content Type is typically deployed at the 'Site' (Site Collection) scope.

questions.text: What is a 'Feature Receiver'?
answers: A C# class (inheriting from `SPFeatureReceiver`) that runs code in response to Feature events (like 'FeatureActivating' or 'FeatureDeactivating').
A radio device for receiving SharePoint signals.
A web page for managing Features.
A log file that lists all activated features.
questions.correctAnswer: A C# class (inheriting from `SPFeatureReceiver`) that runs code in response to Feature events (like 'FeatureActivating' or 'FeatureDeactivating').
questions.explanation: This is commonly used in SSOM to programmatically create lists, set permissions, or perform other setup tasks when a Feature is activated.

questions.text: The PowerShell command `Install-SPSolution` is used to deploy a `.wsp` Farm Solution.
questions.explanation: Deploying a WSP is a two-step process: first, `Add-SPSolution` (which uploads it to the farm's solution store), then `Install-SPSolution` (which deploys it to the specific web application).

questions.text: What is the 'App Catalog'?
answers: A special Site Collection in SharePoint Online (or on-prem) used to upload and manage Add-in (`.app`) and SPFx (`.sppkg`) packages.
The folder where SharePoint Designer stores files.
questions.correctAnswer: A special Site Collection in SharePoint Online (or on-prem) used to upload and manage Add-in (`.app`) and SPFx (`.sppkg`) packages.
questions.explanation: Instead of deploying to the GAC, modern solutions (Add-ins and SPFx) are uploaded to the App Catalog, making them available for users to install on their sites.

questions.text: The file format for a deployable SharePoint Framework (SPFx) solution is `___`.
questions.explanation: The `gulp package-solution` command creates a `.sppkg` file, which is a package (similar to a .wsp) that is uploaded to the App Catalog.

questions.text: In a WSP, the `manifest.xml` file is...
answers: The same as the `AppManifest.xml` for an Add-in.
A file that defines all the Features, assemblies, and other files included in the solution package.
A log file of the deployment.
A file that requests permissions for the solution.
questions.correctAnswer: A file that defines all the Features, assemblies, and other files included in the solution package.
questions.explanation: The `manifest.xml` is the central file in the WSP package that tells SharePoint which files go where and which Features are included in the solution.

questions.text: You can deploy a Farm Solution (`.wsp`) to SharePoint Online.
questions.explanation: Farm Solutions require server-side GAC deployment and access to the SSOM, which is impossible in the multi-tenant SharePoint Online environment. They are strictly for on-premises.

questions.text: What is 'Role Inheritance' in SharePoint security?
answers: The concept that a user's role (e.g., Manager) inherits from their department.
The default behavior where a securable object (like a site, list, or item) uses the same permissions as its parent container.
A type of C# class inheritance for security models.
A feature that is only available in Active Directory.
questions.correctAnswer: The default behavior where a securable object (like a site, list, or item) uses the same permissions as its parent container.
questions.explanation: By default, a subsite inherits permissions from its parent site, a list inherits from its site, and an item inherits from its list. You can 'break' this inheritance to set unique permissions.

questions.text: What are the three main building blocks of SharePoint permissions?
answers: Active Directory, Azure AD, and SQL
questions.explanation: Permissions are managed by adding Users to SharePoint Groups, and then assigning those Groups a Permission Level (e.g., 'Read', 'Contribute') on a securable object (like a site).

questions.text: A 'Permission Level' (e.g., 'Read' or 'Contribute') is a collection of individual permissions (e.g., 'View Items', 'Add Items').
questions.explanation: Permission Levels (like 'Contribute') are simply named collections of granular rights (like 'Add Items', 'Edit Items', 'Delete Items') that make permissions easier to manage.

questions.text: What is an 'App-Only' Context in CSOM or Add-in development?
answers: A context where the application has no permissions.
A security context where the application authenticates using its own identity (e.g., Client ID/Secret) and permissions, *not* the user's.
A context that only allows reading from the App Catalog.
questions.correctAnswer: A security context where the application authenticates using its own identity (e.g., Client ID/Secret) and permissions, *not* the user's.
questions.explanation: This is crucial for backend processes (like timer jobs or APIs) that need to run with elevated, consistent permissions regardless of which user triggered them.

questions.text: In SSOM, `SPWeb.AllowUnsafeUpdates = true` is required to:
answers: Make changes to SharePoint data from a `GET` request or when the Form Digest is invalid.
questions.correctAnswer: Make changes to SharePoint data from a `GET` request or when the Form Digest is invalid.
questions.explanation: This bypasses SharePoint's built-in CSRF protection (the Form Digest). It's required in some contexts (like event receivers) but should be set to `false` as soon as possible.

questions.text: Breaking permission inheritance on a list with 50,000 items is a good practice and has no performance impact.
questions.explanation: This is a very bad practice. Unique permissions (item-level) are extremely performance-intensive and can make the list unusable. The supported limit for unique permissions in a list is ~50,000, but performance degrades long before that.

questions.text: What is the difference between `site.RootWeb` and `web` in `SPContext.Current`?
answers: No difference, they point to the same object.
`site.RootWeb` is the top-level site of the Site Collection, while `web` is the specific subsite the user is currently on.
`web` is the top-level site, and `site.RootWeb` is the subsite.
questions.correctAnswer: `site.RootWeb` is the top-level site of the Site Collection, while `web` is the specific subsite the user is currently on.
questions.explanation: In SSOM, `SPContext.Current.Site` is the `SPSite` (Site Collection). `SPContext.Current.Web` is the `SPWeb` (Site) the user is browsing. `site.RootWeb` always refers to the top-level `SPWeb` of that `SPSite`.

questions.text: A ___ is a C# class used to define custom, claim-based authentication for a Web Application (e.g., logging in via a non-Windows system).
questions.explanation: In on-premises (SharePoint 2010+), you can create a Custom Claims Provider to integrate with external identity systems (like Forms-Based Authentication) and augment user tokens with custom claims.

questions.text: SharePoint Online (SPO) uses `___` as its primary identity provider.
questions.explanation: All users, groups, and app authentications for Microsoft 365, including SharePoint Online, are managed by Azure Active Directory.

questions.text: A 'Remote Event Receiver' (RER) is a C# web service (API) that runs on the SharePoint server.
questions.explanation: A Remote Event Receiver is a web service (e.g., a C# Web API) that runs *externally* (like a Provider-Hosted Add-in). SharePoint *calls* this remote endpoint when an event (like 'ItemAdding') occurs.

questions.text: What is `SPUser` vs `SPPrincipal` in SSOM?
answers: `SPUser` is a user, `SPPrincipal` is a group.
`SPPrincipal` is the base class for both `SPUser` and `SPGroup`.
`SPPrincipal` is for on-prem, `SPUser` is for online.
questions.correctAnswer: `SPPrincipal` is the base class for both `SPUser` and `SPGroup`.
questions.explanation: When managing permissions, you often work with `SPPrincipal` because the object you are adding could be either a single user (`SPUser`) or a security group (`SPGroup`).

questions.text: What is an `SPRoleDefinition` in SSOM?
answers: A user's job title from their profile.
An object representing a Permission Level (e.g., 'Read', 'Contribute').
A role in an Active Directory group.
questions.correctAnswer: An object representing a Permission Level (e.g., 'Read', 'Contribute').
questions.explanation: An `SPRoleDefinition` (Permission Level) is bound to an `SPPrincipal` (User/Group) on a securable object using an `SPRoleAssignment`.

questions.text: The permission `SPBasePermissions.EmptyMask` represents having no permissions.
questions.explanation: This bitmask is used in security operations to define a baseline of no access, which is often used when creating 'Limited Access' permission levels.

questions.text: To get a user's C# `SPUser` object from an `SPWeb`, you use `___`.
questions.explanation: `web.EnsureUser(loginName)` will check if the user is in the site's User Information List. If they are, it returns the `SPUser` object. If not, it adds them and then returns the object.

questions.text: It is a best practice to add users directly to a list or item to grant permissions.
questions.explanation: Best practice is to always add users to SharePoint Groups, and then assign permissions to the Groups. This makes managing permissions (e.g., removing a user) much simpler.

questions.text: What does CAML stand for?
questions.explanation: CAML is the XML-based query language used to query SharePoint lists in SSOM, CSOM, and the REST API.

questions.text: A CAML query is used to query:
questions.explanation: CAML is specifically designed for querying `SPList` objects. To query across the farm or multiple site collections, you must use the Search API (with KQL).

questions.text: What is KQL (Keyword Query Language)?
answers: A C#-based query language for lists.
The primary query language used by the SharePoint Search API to find content across the farm/tenant.
A language for creating keywords in the Term Store.
questions.correctAnswer: The primary query language used by the SharePoint Search API to find content across the farm/tenant.
questions.explanation: KQL is a powerful text-based language (e.g., `Title:Contract AND FileType:pdf`) used to query the search index via CSOM, REST, or search-driven web parts.

questions.text: In a CAML query, what tag is used to filter results (e.g., 'Status' equals 'Complete')?
questions.explanation: The `<Where>` tag contains the logic for filtering, typically using comparison tags like `<Eq>` (Equals), `<Gt>` (Greater Than), and logical joins like `<And>` or `<Or>`.

questions.text: In Search, what is a 'Crawled Property'?
answers: Raw metadata discovered by the search crawler (e.g., a specific site column named 'ProjectManager').
A property that is 'crawling' (i.e., slow to query).
A property that is available in KQL queries.
questions.correctAnswer: Raw metadata discovered by the search crawler (e.g., a specific site column named 'ProjectManager').
questions.explanation: Crawled Properties are the raw metadata. They are not usable in queries until they are mapped to a Managed Property.

questions.text: In Search, what is a 'Managed Property'?
answers: The same as a Crawled Property.
A property in the search schema (e.g., 'ProjectManagerManaged') that is mapped to one or more Crawled Properties and can be used in KQL queries.
A property managed by a C# application.
questions.correctAnswer: A property in the search schema (e.g., 'ProjectManagerManaged') that is mapped to one or more Crawled Properties and can be used in KQL queries.
questions.explanation: To make a custom column searchable (e.g., `ProjectManagerManaged:'John Doe'`), you *must* map its Crawled Property to a Managed Property in the Search Schema.

questions.text: You can use KQL to query a single SharePoint list.
questions.explanation: Yes, you can scope a KQL query to a specific list or site using `Path:` or `ListID:`. This is often much faster than CAML for large lists.

questions.text: In CAML, the `<ViewFields>` tag is used to specify which columns to return.
questions.explanation: Similar to a SQL `SELECT` statement, `<ViewFields>` allows you to specify only the fields you need, which is a critical performance optimization.

questions.text: What is the `RowLimit` in a CAML query?
answers: The maximum number of rows a list can have.
A tag (`<RowLimit>`) that specifies the maximum number of items to return in a single query.
A limit on how many characters can be in one row.
The limit on how many fields can be returned.
questions.correctAnswer: A tag (`<RowLimit>`) that specifies the maximum number of items to return in a single query.
questions.explanation: This is essential for paging and for avoiding the 'List View Threshold' error by ensuring your query never tries to process more than 5,000 items at once.

questions.text: What is the 'List View Threshold'?
answers: The maximum number of views a list can have.
The maximum number of items a list can store (which is 30 million).
An on-prem server setting (default 5,000) that prevents queries from running if they would affect more than that many items at one time.
The maximum number of users who can view a list.
questions.correctAnswer: An on-prem server setting (default 5,000) that prevents queries from running if they would affect more than that many items at one time.
questions.explanation: This is the most common error C# developers face. To query a large list, you *must* use an indexed column in your CAML `<Where>` clause to ensure the query doesn't scan more than 5,000 items.

questions.text: You can avoid the List View Threshold by using KQL (Search API) instead of CAML.
questions.explanation: The Search API (KQL) queries the search index, *not* the live SQL database, so it is not subject to the List View Threshold. This is the recommended way to query large lists.

questions.text: To query a lookup column in CAML, you must query against the `___`.
questions.explanation: You cannot filter a CAML query by the *text* of a lookup field. You must filter by its ID, e.g., `<Eq><FieldRef Name='MyLookup' LookupId='TRUE'/><Value Type='Integer'>123</Value></Eq>`.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `SPQuery.ViewFieldsOnly` property in SSOM?
answers: It ensures the query *only* returns fields specified in `<ViewFields>`, improving performance by not joining to other tables.
It forces the query to only use the fields in the 'Default View'.
questions.correctAnswer: It ensures the query *only* returns fields specified in `<ViewFields>`, improving performance by not joining to other tables.
questions.explanation: Setting `SPQuery.ViewFieldsOnly = true` is a major performance optimization, as it prevents SharePoint from doing extra work to fetch all available fields for the items.

questions.text: KQL is case-sensitive.
questions.explanation: KQL is case-insensitive for both keywords (e.g., `Title:`) and values (e.g., `'Contract'`).

questions.text: The `ContentSearch` C# namespace (`Microsoft.Office.Server.Search.Query`) is used for what?
answers: Executing KQL queries using the Search API (e.g., `KeywordQuery`) in SSOM or CSOM.
Searching for content in a .wsp package.
Searching the Managed Metadata Term Store.
questions.correctAnswer: Executing KQL queries using the Search API (e.g., `KeywordQuery`) in SSOM or CSOM.
questions.explanation: This is the C# API for programmatically building and executing search queries against the SharePoint Search Service Application.

questions.text: What is the modern, cloud-first service for building business workflows and processes in Microsoft 365?
questions.explanation: Power Automate is the standard for modern business process automation. It is part of the Power Platform and integrates deeply with SharePoint Online.

questions.text: SharePoint Designer 2013 is the recommended tool for building new workflows in SharePoint Online.
questions.explanation: SharePoint Designer 2013 workflows are deprecated in Microsoft 365. All new workflows should be built using Power Automate.

questions.text: What is a 'Remote Event Receiver' (RER)?
answers: A classic SSOM event receiver that runs on the server.
A C# web service (API) endpoint that SharePoint calls *remotely* when an event (e.g., 'ItemAdded') occurs.
A local event receiver on a client's machine.
questions.correctAnswer: A C# web service (API) endpoint that SharePoint calls *remotely* when an event (e.g., 'ItemAdded') occurs.
questions.explanation: RERs were the cloud-friendly (Add-in model) way to replace SSOM event receivers. They are C# Web APIs hosted externally (e.g., Azure) that SharePoint calls.

questions.text: What is the C# class for building classic (SSOM) event receivers?
questions.explanation: You create a C# class that inherits from one of the `SP...EventReceiver` base classes and override its methods (e.g., `ItemAdding`, `ItemAdded`).

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a synchronous (`-ing`) and asynchronous (`-ed`) event receiver?
answers: Synchronous runs before the action (e.g., `ItemAdding`) and can cancel it; Asynchronous runs after (e.g., `ItemAdded`).
Synchronous runs on the server; Asynchronous runs in the browser.
Synchronous is for CSOM; Asynchronous is for SSOM.
questions.correctAnswer: Synchronous runs before the action (e.g., `ItemAdding`) and can cancel it; Asynchronous runs after (e.g., `ItemAdded`).
questions.explanation: Synchronous '...ing' events are used for validation (e.g., canceling an item update if data is invalid). Asynchronous '...ed' events are for triggering follow-up actions (e.g., sending an email).

questions.text: A C# developer can create custom workflow activities for use in SharePoint Designer 2013 (on-prem).
questions.explanation: Using SSOM (inheriting from the `Activity` class in `System.Workflow.ComponentModel`) and deploying in a WSP, a C# developer can create custom, reusable actions that appear in SharePoint Designer.

questions.text: In Power Automate, a flow that starts when a SharePoint item is created is triggered by a `___`.
questions.explanation: All automated flows start with a 'Trigger' (e.g., 'When an item is created or modified'). The subsequent steps are called 'Actions'.

questions.text: What Power Platform tool is used to customize SharePoint list forms (e.g., `NewForm.aspx`)?
questions.explanation: Power Apps is integrated with modern SharePoint lists to allow developers to create rich, custom forms with complex logic, replacing old tools like InfoPath.

questions.text: A 'declarative' workflow (made in SharePoint Designer) is compiled into C# code.
questions.explanation: SharePoint Designer workflows (2010) were declarative (XAML-based) but were compiled into C# code on the server. 2013 workflows run in a separate service (Workflow Manager).

questions.text: Remote Event Receivers (RERs) can only be asynchronous (`-ed`) events.
questions.explanation: RERs can be both asynchronous (`-ed`) and synchronous (`-ing`). A synchronous RER (e.g., `ItemAdding`) must return a specific success/failure status quickly, or the user's action will time out.

questions.text: In classic SharePoint branding (on-prem), what file controls the overall 'chrome' (header, footer, navigation) of a site?
questions.explanation: Classic SharePoint used Master Pages (like ASP.NET Web Forms) to define the shared layout and chrome for all pages in a site.

questions.text: In classic publishing sites, what file defines the editable 'field controls' for a specific type of page (like a News Article)?
questions.explanation: A Page Layout is tied to a Content Type and defines the specific layout and editable regions for a page created in the 'Pages' library.

questions.text: Modern SharePoint Online sites (Communication, Team) use Master Pages and Page Layouts for branding.
questions.explanation: Modern sites do not support custom Master Pages or Page Layouts. Customization is done via SPFx Extensions (Application Customizers), Site Designs, and tenant-level Theming.

questions.text: What is the Microsoft Graph API?
answers: A SharePoint-only REST API for creating graphs and charts.
A single, unified REST endpoint (`graph.microsoft.com`) for accessing data from multiple Microsoft 365 services (SharePoint, Teams, Outlook, Users).
A C# library for drawing graphics.
questions.correctAnswer: A single, unified REST endpoint (`graph.microsoft.com`) for accessing data from multiple Microsoft 365 services (SharePoint, Teams, Outlook, Users).
questions.explanation: Microsoft Graph is the future of M365 development, providing one API and one auth model to access data from all services, including SharePoint files, sites, and lists.

questions.text: A C# developer can call the Microsoft Graph API from a .NET Web API or Azure Function.
questions.explanation: This is a very common pattern. A C# backend service (using the Microsoft Graph SDK for .NET) authenticates to Azure AD and calls the Graph API to perform operations on behalf of a user or as an application.

questions.text: What is the Microsoft Graph endpoint to get the files in the default Document Library of a site?
questions.explanation: The Graph API treats the default document library as a 'Drive'. The endpoint `/sites/{site-id}/drive` (or `/groups/{group-id}/drive` for Team Sites) is the entry point for file operations.

questions.text: A 'Site Design' and 'Site Script' in modern SharePoint are used to:
answers: Write custom C# code for a site.
Define a repeatable template (e.g., create lists, apply a theme) that is applied when a new modern site is created.
questions.correctAnswer: Define a repeatable template (e.g., create lists, apply a theme) that is applied when a new modern site is created.
questions.explanation: Site Scripts are JSON files defining actions (like `createList`). Site Designs are the user-facing templates (e.g., 'Project Site') that apply one or more Site Scripts.

questions.text: In classic branding, the `___` folder (mapped to `_layouts/15`) was often used to deploy custom CSS and JavaScript files in a WSP.
questions.explanation: The `Layouts` mapped folder in a Visual Studio solution would deploy files to the `_layouts/15` directory on the server's file system, making them globally available to all sites in the farm.

questions.text: The Microsoft Graph API is replacing the need for the SharePoint-specific REST API (`_api/`).
questions.explanation: While the `_api` still works and has some features Graph doesn't, Microsoft's official guidance is to use the Microsoft Graph API whenever possible for all new development.

questions.text: To use the C# Microsoft Graph SDK, you must first authenticate and get an `___`.
questions.explanation: All Graph API calls must be authenticated using an OAuth 2.0 Access Token, which is typically acquired using the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL) for .NET.
